abstract.p: Letter from John J Drummond comments on cracking genetic code of human life and need to remember 'human' aspect of human genome

block.p: Re ''Genetic Code of Human Life Is Cracked by Scientists'' (front page, June 27):

Re ''Genetic Code of Human Life Is Cracked by Scientists'' (front page, June 27):
Scientists are certainly correct that the decoding of the human genome reveals the extent to which we are a part of nature. To be sure, however, we should add a qualification.

No other part of nature has made these discoveries. No other part of nature speaks, reads or discusses these discoveries. No other part of nature hopes that they will be bountiful in preventing and treating disease and disorder. No other part of nature reflects on the moral significance of these discoveries.
Let's not forget the ''human'' in ''human genome,'' and the not merely molecular ways in which we are distinguished within nature.
JOHN J. DRUMMOND Pelham, N.Y., June 28, 2000
The writer is a professor of philosophy at Fordham University.
